header: ISD Political Readiness Assessment Tool — Designed by DB
welcome: Welcome to the Political Readiness Assessment

questions.text: When a complex issue like unemployment or waste management arises in your constituency, what’s your first response?

options.text: I bring together local experts and citizens to co-create solutions and implement them.
I study successful examples from other regions and adapt them locally.
I consult my team or local officials for advice and depend on their suggestions.
I wait for higher authorities or my party to guide or intervene.

questions.text: When a government scheme has low uptake in your area, how do you help citizens access it?

options.text: I personally study the scheme, identify barriers, and mobilize local volunteers to spread awareness.
I delegate the work to my team but track progress regularly.
I inform citizens when they approach me but don’t take active steps.
I assume people will figure it out themselves or the government will handle it.

questions.text: If your party is deciding candidates for the upcoming elections, how do you engage in that process?

options.text: I actively engage with party leaders, share constituency insights, and build consensus on candidate selection.
I stay in contact with key decision-makers and express my interest or recommendations.
I wait to see how internal politics unfold and react accordingly.
I stay neutral and avoid any involvement.

questions.text: When two groups in your party disagree on an issue, what role do you play?

options.text: I mediate the discussion and help both groups find a common ground.
I listen to both sides and support the one closer to my view.
I avoid getting involved to protect my own image.
I side with whoever seems more powerful to maintain my position.

questions.text: During a festival or public event, how do you engage with your community?

options.text: I interact deeply with people, listen to their issues, and strengthen personal connections.
I attend briefly to show presence and greet key people.
I send my team to represent me and collect feedback.
I avoid large gatherings and prefer not to attend.

questions.text: When a team member faces a personal challenge, how do you respond as a leader?

options.text: I offer personal support, ensure they feel cared for, and motivate the rest of the team.
I check in once or twice but focus mostly on ongoing work.
I express sympathy but expect them to manage their own situation.
I avoid involvement as it’s not part of my role.

questions.text: If you suddenly need to organize a political campaign, how would you arrange funds?

options.text: I reach out to my trusted network, mobilize small contributions, and ensure transparent use.
I seek help from friends and close supporters to arrange the basics.
I rely mainly on my party or a few donors for major expenses.
I postpone the campaign until funds become available.

questions.text: When funds are limited, how do you prioritize political or developmental activities?

options.text: I focus on high-impact activities and use creative, low-cost solutions.
I consult my team to decide which activities to cut or delay.
I reduce engagement and wait for better funding.
I stop most activities until money is available.

questions.text: When solving a public problem requires cooperation across departments, what do you do?

options.text: I personally reach out to officials, media, and influencers to coordinate joint action.
I ask my team to follow up and connect me only when necessary.
I send formal letters or requests and wait for responses.
I avoid involvement, assuming it’s outside my control.

questions.text: How often do you engage journalists, businesspeople, or government officials to strengthen cooperation?

options.text: Regularly — I maintain active and mutually beneficial relationships.
Occasionally — I reach out only when there’s a pressing issue.
Rarely — I prefer to stay within my political circle.
Never — I feel such connections don’t make much difference.

questions.text: If you lose an important political opportunity (like a ticket or election), how do you respond?

options.text: I stay committed to my values and continue public work without bitterness.
I reflect, take feedback, and prepare better for the future.
I distance myself temporarily from political activities.
I blame others or withdraw from the process completely.

questions.text: When a policy decision clashes with your moral values, what stance do you take?

options.text: I voice my concern publicly and stand by my principles.
I raise the issue privately with leadership.
I quietly follow the majority to avoid conflict.
I ignore my discomfort to protect my position.
